body: Same here, have you resolved this issue?

My solution so far has been to run `mlflow run` inside the docker container (with `--no-conda` and no docker container specified in the project definition).

Effectively bypassing the feature, I guess.

Even if the feature could use GPUs. I think I prefer it this way since I'm launching these containers in Kubernetes.
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.
Still a blocker unless an update has solved it.

We are also interested. We don't want to set the default runtime to nvidia also..
Thank you for interacting with this issue! Removing the stale label!

This would be a good first issue. We could extend the MLproject spec to support a new `runtime` field in the `docker_env` configuration block. E.g.
```
docker_env:
  image: mlflow-docker-example-environment
  runtime: nvidia
```
then update `_get_docker_command` in `mlflow/projects/_init.py` and its [invocation](https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/889e46269256c3bef5c9744312fd860c0136521a/mlflow/projects/__init__.py#L154) to process the `runtime` parameter and add it to the command arguments. If someone picks this up, it would be great to add tests and update the documentation.

+1 @tomasatdatabricks 

It would be great in general if we could just pass arbitrary `docker run` arguments (like I would pass `-gpus all`, might want to modify `--ipc`, etc.). Having MLflow handle training without GPU support just doesn't make sense without it...
Yeah, this is mandatory for me. Hoping to see some progress here.
@ksanjeevan good points - perhaps instead of a `runtime` parameter, we should instead allow `additional-arguments` or something similar. We would love a community contribution on this issue!
@pogil Maybe this issue should be merged with https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/issues/2607 ?
